Posts.Content: May 9, 2013 12:25PM chefmiche wrote: My orthopedic surgeon told me that anytime the weather is cold or if your altitude changes, like on a flight to expect more bone pain.  It is true!!

Posts.Title: Ritalin again raro K-Lo

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2012 02:39PM chefmiche wrote: I went to my infusion today and my MO agreed to give me prescription of 5 mg of Ritalin.  Yay, I hope it helps!  Her nurse told me that dr doesn't normally prescribe it to her patients but if it works for me she may start!  Fingers crossed!  Thanks for the advice!
Posts.Title: Ritalin again raro K-Lo

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2013 01:10PM chefmiche wrote: Hi all, Michele here, I am 42 and was dx with Stage IV Sept 2011.  I had been living life cancer free since 2007 where I was told after my bmx I was cancer free.  I went through chemo, bmx, rads, then reconstruction then celebrated on a cruise that i was cancer free with 10 women I love.  I met the man of my dreams in 2009, we fell in love and after my bad news of cancer returning mets to bone in Sept 2011, (hips, spine, skull) he asked me to marry him.  I have went through rads on my hips and spine x 15 and had ooph, and hysterectomy, took aromasin and zometa and was NED for 8 months, had a hip surgery to fill hole tumor caused, and fracture with cement and yesterday found out there is progression that the aromasin has failed and I have a new tumor in my rib (which I didn't have symtoms for).  Last Jan (1 year ago) my onc advised me to go on SSDI due to my hip pain preventing me from sitting/standing/walking for too long without pain.  I am now on 50 mcg fentanyl and after yesterday's appt with onc am going to start taking new pain drug for breakthrough called Fentora and stop Zometa and start Xgeva which I got the shot today.  We are trying to get my insur to approve Affinitor to take with the Aromasin but so far no luck.  My dr seems optimistic that they will approve with the appeal they filed today.  My husband is a realtor so he has a flexible schedule, and since I am home from work, I am a dogmom, the chef (I love to cook) and housewife.  It has been nice to be able to sleep when tired, which is daily naps and at least 9 hours a night (prob from pain meds).  I am hoping I won't have bad SE with new Xgeva, Affinitor and Fenator pain med.  I have been so thankful to have these boards to refer to.  I feel that I have gotten such valuable information here that when my dr told me yesterday I had progression, I really was prepared for that, since I have read so many stories on here like that.  I wasn't scared and I don't feel devastated like I did at initial dx.  My new normal life has changed drasticly, now I need to plan my day including a nap, I try to do only 1 thing a day to keep pain at min. and really try to be good to myself.  I have been on a rollercoaster of emotions this past 16 months, but because I read from others on here I am not alone.  I do have wonderful family, terrific friends, a great therapist, my DH who is my rock, and you women who I don't know personally but have helped me so much.  Thanks so much for being real.  Great topic!!
Posts.Title: Roll Call 2013 LilSchatzie reader123

Posts.Content: chefmiche wrote: I am going to try 2 gallons of Kangen water and wondered what results anyone has seen from using it?  I am curious if it helps or another "gimmick" for sale. Chemotherapy 7/10/2007 AC + T (Taxol) Surgery 11/23/2007 Mastectomy: Left, Right Hormonal Therapy 11/29/2007 Radiation Therapy 1/15/2008 Breast Surgery 4/15/2008 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap, Nipple reconstruction; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap, Nipple reconstruction Dx 9/2011, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 9/28/2011 Aromasin (exemestane) Radiation Therapy 10/5/2011 Bone Surgery 12/9/2011 Prophylactic ovary removal Targeted Therapy 1/29/2013 Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy 5/13/2013 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 3/13/2014 Gemzar (gemcitabine) Hormonal Therapy 8/14/2014 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Radiation Therapy 11/11/2014 Bone Chemotherapy 2/6/2015 Halaven (eribulin) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Kangen water, has it helped you? chefmiche SPAMgirl

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2012 06:41PM chefmiche wrote: I am so skeptical about things that include a multi-level marketing system, which the machine that makes the ionized water is part of.  But I ran into a man at Trader Joes when I was looking at the electrolyte water he offered to give me 2 gallons free of Kangen water and another facebook friend offered as well, but I know they want to "hook" me and get me to buy the $1200-$5000 water system, which I can't afford.  I figure if it did really "cure cancer" or cure obesity, or any of the other things they say it does, than everyone would know about it and use it, it wouldn't be a "secret".  I was just curious because the man seemed nice enough and even went so far as to tell me he wants to help heal me by giving me the water, it makes me upset that any company would use people's illnesses to sell a product if it weren't true.  I have heard though eating alkaline versus acidic is good, but not real sure about that either....  Thanks for your feedback, love these boards, you all are a wealth of information!!!
Posts.Title: Kangen water, has it helped you? chefmiche SPAMgirl

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2012 08:13AM chefmiche wrote: I think the article was very well written and educating!  I bet people will appreciate the information!  I know I did :)  Thanks so much
Posts.Title: My Message re MBC Bestbird Heidihill

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2013 05:47PM chefmiche wrote: Welcome Redhead, I am a fellow redhead myself, and have bone mets too.  These boards have given me so much info that is invaluable.  More than a few min with my onc office ever has.  I had never heard of Metastatic breast cancer before I was dx.  I think most people I know have never heard of it either, and it is a scary place to be in, especially the first few months.  Some days it is still hard and I am 15 months out from dx.  I am finally on a good pain mngmnt plan and that helped a lot, plus the stress of work is gone since I went on SSDI.  I am 42 so mentally I wasn't ready to quit but my pain wouldn't allow it.  I have been open with my family and friends and started a caringbridge site I started when I first had BC in 2007 and that has helped me emensly keep everyone on board.  Although I know there is no cure, I am starting to beleive there must be a reason for this, maybe somehow I am going to help someone or one day I will know the reason for this path, I for now, trust God knows best and I will continue to pray for His will be done in my life.  I have found there are so many blessings that have come along with the bad news.  I try to stay focused on all the good things, but I know that is hard especially if feeling pain or sick or tired.  I love coming on here and learning from those that came before us and although it is hard to see others pass on these boards, it is part of our path, unfortunately.  Someday maybe in our near future they will find a cure, but if not, enjoy as much as you can.  Glad you introduced yourself!
Posts.Title: Out of lurking, introducing myself redheadinwv SchnauzerMom

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 09:15AM - edited Feb 1, 2013 09:16AM by chefmiche I started Cymbalta over 2 weeks ago and I was taking Celexa before and went to the doc thinking I had a low thyroid because I had no energy, was sleeping a lot, cried easily and felt terrible.  AND was using a lot of breakthru pain meds along with my 50 mcg Fentanyl patch.  My dr said it sounded like my anti-depressant wasn't working and maybe Cymbalta would help my pain.  It has!  for the past 8 days I haven't had to take any breakthrough meds for pain.  I am super excited that it is helping my pain!  My onc told me that I have permanent nerve damage where I had surgery to remove a tumor and filled hole with cement in my right hip, that's where my pain has been since Aug 2011.  I hope it helps you!  I haven't noticed SE, take mid morning
Posts.Title: cymbalta for pain bhd1 TXGigi

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2013 01:32AM chefmiche wrote: When I was going to lose my hair in 2007 with chemo I shaved it off before it fell, it felt empowering.  When it first started coming in it was blonde (I am a redhead) and kinky curly, nearly small enough curls to be like afro, then it grew about an inch and it turned red and still very curly which I hoped would stay, but then it finally just grew in almost exactly like it was before I shaved it.  Now I am on chemo pill Afinitor but no hair loss so far but I am letting mine grow now cuz I figure I will lose it at some point with some drug or another we take.  I do remember it feeling like it took awhile to start growing but I was taking so many vitamins at that time it may of helped.  I wonder if shaving it like Brenda said would help or not, not sure but makes sense!  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 02:50PM chefmiche wrote: I was shocked when I was at the onc office for treatment and the financial guy asked to talk to me, I was thinking (I am paying my bills, oh no, am I in trouble??) and he said that I may qualify for assistance from Zometa company.  And bc I am on SSDI I did qualify, I got $5000 credit on my bill which wiped away my debt there and I have credit for my future Zometa infusions...wow, that was awesome!  Now if I can find assistance with my $44,000 hospital bill, apparantly my insurance won't pay any bc my stay was not pre-authorized.  It is in appeal now but if they do pay I will owe $8,000 and then my 3 month scans have a bill that I make payments on that is several thousand dollars....it is overwhelming to think of how expensive it is to have cancer!!!  I hope to find more assistance, good luck to you too!!

I just feel it is due to one of my chemos.
Posts.Title: Toe Nail Just Dropped Off AmyQ Cafelovr

Posts.Content: chefmiche wrote: Sometimes I wonder why do we go through all the side effects, the losing of hair, the fatigue, ect ect etc.  I mean we all know there is no cure for this disease so what is the point of taking meds if they will eventually fail anyway?  I guess we hope that one med will make us be stable or NED for a long time.  What would happen if we didn't do chemo or radiation or meds.  Well besides pain meds if there is pain.  I just wonder why?  I guess like my onc told me in the beginning to help with prolonging our life in the best quality as possible.  I don't know about you all, but I cancel plans with friends/family at least 3-4 times a week due to being too sick or too tired or in pain...  I wonder if I didn't take cancer meds but just pain meds what would happen.  The cancerr would grow and eventually kill me.  Isn't that what is happening anyway taking meds?  Just a rant I suppose.  I wouldn't stop taking meds, just curious what are your thoughts about the subject?? Posts.Title: What is the point of going through this.. chefmiche Jill49

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2013 06:49PM chefmiche wrote: I appreciate all the comments, I guess reading lately about the lovely ladies who have died made me ask...I had a moment of feeling sorry for myself.  But I know it can get worse.  And for me, heck I am 42 and just have bone mets, many of you have way worse problems than hip pain and fatigue.  I guess it is just real hard sometimes knowing I am young and I feel like my 90 yr old grandmother does with the aches and pains and low energy.  I have many things to be grateful for, it is though hard when I know there is no cure now (hopefully someday soon there will be) and people say things to me like "baking soda is the cure", "food grade peroxide is the cure" "hemp oil" so on and so on... It has been hard on me to go from being self sufficient, career woman doing well at work with all the dreams and goals ahead of me, to having cancer and hearing others pass away, thinking maybe I don't have much time either.  I just needed some comradary today.  Thanks for being there!
Posts.Title: What is the point of going through this.. chefmiche Jill49

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 07:22PM - edited Nov 18, 2012 11:40PM by chefmiche I had a co-worker say to me "my mother in law had BC and it traveled to her brain and she died" when I had just found out the day before I had BC. People tell me all the time "you don't look sick" My onc recommended I go on SSDI, quit my stressful job in Feb, last month I saw her and she said "now are you working?"  I was thinking...uh...you told me not to!  (she must have a lot of patients..) People say "you should be happy, you are NED" like the cancer is gone??  This confuses me.....is it? "Think positive" it's all in your attitude... My favorite is "you are amazing, so strong, you can beat this!" I didn't chose this path, or even want this path, how can I be amazing, I am just doing what I have to do to get through... "If you have unresolved issues it will keep you sick" "God has healed you" has he?  I would love to beleive that!

Posts.Content: chefmiche wrote: Ladies, I have read where several of you have had osteo-necrosis of the jaw (ONJ), the dreaded side effect of Zometa/Xgeva etc but I haven't read what it feels like?  I have been experiencing jaw acheyness for the last 2 days.  I don't see any signs of it but I am paranoid I may be starting to have it.  I wear a Fentanyl 50 mcg pain patch and take Cymbalta 60 mg (that helps a lot with skeltal pain)and have break through meds for pain, Diladad and also Fentora (take pain meds for bone mets pain in hip mostly) but none has helped with this jaw aches.  I haven't had any dental work done recently but am taking antibiotics (Levaquin) and gargling with Pink Magic mouthwash for a throat infection.  I have an ice pack on my jaw (only the left side hurts) let's see if that helps.  I also have been rinsing with Biotene 3 times a day for a month since I started Afinitor with Aromasin.  Can any of you with ONJ describe what it felt like in the beginning and how do you confirm that is the case?  Any words of advice will be appreciated!! Posts.Content: May 24, 2013 11:32AM chefmiche wrote: I agree Bon, why should we have to beg?  There is no repercussions if we live longer than the 12 months in my case, the money would not be repaid by me or MO.  They don't even follow up after to check to see if we are alive or not is what I was told by the Life Insurance company.  So if she tells me no (if I get the nerve up to ask) it seems very unfair of her since we didn't have a choice to stop working or to get this disease, why not make it easier to pay the large medical bills we get!  Hard to understand.  I think I will have a problem with my onc if she tells me no.  But I will have to get over it.  Unless I go to my pain Dr and ask her to sign.  My therapist offered to sign it for me, would that count?  Prob not.  It's not like it's a lot of money in my case, ($50K).  That would change my life if I had that cash though!

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2013 08:00AM chefmiche wrote: i did ask my onc and she did sign papers and i received the money it has totally changed our life by paying off debt and lessen our monthly bills so not as much pressure on my hubby which helps us a lot! I also learned of a program here locally called WINGS that helps bc women pay for COBRA and other things too!  There are so many resources out there for us...which is great!

Posts.Content: chefmiche wrote: Hi there, I have been on LTD from work for over a year and in Oct I will be terminated from the company, it will be 2 years since I've worked and my insurance will end.  I called to get COBRA info and for me it will cost $585 and double with my spouse.  I am on SSDI and medicare will begin next April in 2014 and I don't want to pay COBRA for 6 months, that is so expensive I wonder can I get good insurance cheaper?  Also once on Medicare do I need to get supplemental insurance?  I am 42 years old.  Just wondering what you know about insurance.  Currently my co has BCBS and it has been really good insur I hate to lose it but cant afford COBRA.  My husband is realtor and co doesn't offer insur so can't get it through his company unfortunately. Posts.Content: chefmiche wrote: I was told in April that my oncologist would like to say I am in remission but at this dx that would never be the case so she is saying I am stable.  Is that the same as NED?  (I have been saying I was NED since April, but now after reading different things on here am wondering if I inferred that somehow, or did she say that?  Now I am confused) I would like to know what is the difference? Also, I am trying to figure out, now that I am feeling better, should I go back to work?  My onc told me in April when I asked her, to stay off for a year to see what the pattern of the cancer would be and in a year I felt the same to ask again.  I wonder if something happens how hard is it to get back on SSDI?  My DH doesn't want me to go back to work because he feels that it is more stressful to work.  I am 41 yrs old and frankly now that my pain is under control (back on Fentanyl 12 mcg patch) I feel a little guilty for not contributing to the household/society.  I realize this is a personal decision but I would love to hear feedback from those of you who have a strong opinion on the subject. Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2013 08:40PM chefmiche wrote: I went to my billing department once to ask about my balance and the guy told me that since I was on Zometa (at that time) there was a Zometa card which helped with the cost, in fact I was qualified due to my loss of income going on SSDI the manufacturer paid $5000 toward my balance which I didn't have so as long as I was on that drug they would pay towards my usage of that drug up to  $5000 so that was a nice surprise.  I am now on Afinitor/Aromasin combo and I am on a copay plan through Afinitor that allows me to pay only $50 a month for that drug to come in the mail.  Yes, so check with your billing department first maybe you will have a knowledgeable lemployee like I did to help you.  Or like Chickadee suggested you could also check with them.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Starting Afinitor and Aromasin, what to expect? hope10 Rseman

Posts.Content: May 23, 2013 12:06PM chefmiche wrote: I had so much pain in beginning of getting dx already I had been taking muscle relaxers because my MD said I prob had pulled a muscle, so I was having a hard time at work and when I was told I had been dx with IV MBC, and they wanted to start me on pain meds for my hip pain, I was then unable to work due to the pain and pain meds, my pain kept getting worse so I had went on STD which then turned into LTD and like it has been said already LTD required me to apply for SSDI, which I was approved immediately and it had been 6 months since I had been at work that the SSDI started pretty quick after application.  My company will continue to pay LTD until retirement age, but they deduct what SSDI pays, which totals 60% of my pay.  I had to sell my car and use my 401k (which I was auto qualified to have full access to after going on LTD) money to pay off most of my debts.  That was nice, except for tax time that 401k money showed as income and had more to repay.  UGH.  My company does offer 1 times my annual salary on the Accelerated Death policy, I looked up my employee handbook to see it in writing, bc, when I called my co hr serv center 800# the person who answered the phone didn't know what I was talking about, and I got discouraged until I used the words Accelerated death benefits through Life insurance.  They transferred me to the Life insurance company to ask for the form. I wish I could get my onc to sign the Accelerated Benefits form, I could use that money!  I know she won't sign it due to me asking her my life expectancy (hoping she would say less than a year, which my form requires her to say) recently and she said "I know you won't die in one year and maybe not even 2 years, but not sure after that.  I just don't think I can ask her to sign the form knowing she thinks I will live longer than a year or two.  But she did say that before I had progression and had to stop A/A and move to Xeloda this month, maybe she would sign it now, I am chicken though.  My empoyer will terminate me on last day of September of this year and COBRA begins Oct 1st, which will be very expensive.  My onc office knows of a Medicaid program for breast cancer and ovarian cancer patients in treatment, but when he called to see if I qualified for the program, the person he asked said that I was not qualified due to me taking oral chemo and that wasn't the same as iv chemo.  My onc said Xeloda is just as much a chemo as any iv chemo would be so she said she would check into that for me.  I wish there was a person that handed a newly dx patient a list of contact #s for programs and companies, organizations that help either with co-pay assistance, or help with cost of meds, and all the info needed when you have to leave your job.  It has felt like a mystery I  have to solve to find out what to do, luckilly I have this site to refer to where I get most of my info, thanks so much!
Posts.Title: Can you get SSDI and short term/long term disability? LizLemon Chickadee

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2012 08:03PM chefmiche wrote: After reading your original post, Sept 2011, I was in a very similar situation.  In 2007 I had stage 2 bc, double masectomy, chemo radiation, 8 surgeries and then thought I was going to celebrate 5 years until Sept 2011 I was told my cancer was back and had metasisized in my bones.  I was in a lot of pain due to the tumor located in my right hip caused fracture and a hole that this year in March the surgeon went in to fill with cement after a failed attempt of cement injection in Dec.  I did radiation on my hips and spine and the pain didn't go away so I was on STD, then LTD and now I was advised to go on SSDI which I got approved in April.  Because of the pain I have been on a pain patch and I think that makes me tired so I nap every day.  I was unsure whether or not to go back to work when April I was told I was NED and other than being tired I feel pretty normal, but I do Zometa monthly infusion and get scans every 3 months and my job was very stressful my new DH and I decided I would go ahead and stay home and rest and try to live a stress free life.  It has it's moments of being wonderful and then there are days I wish I did work but honestly it is nice to not have to at least for now.  I did need to make many changes financially to afford to take less pay but it has been a good decision for now.  My doc wants me to stay home for a year and see what the pattern is of the cancer and see how I feel in a year and then decide what to do.  Life is very short and for us this works for now.  I wonder how you are doing now since time has passed since you wrote, what did you end up deciding to do?  This site has been great to see how others are doing with the Stage IV dx.  That in itself sounds so scary!
Posts.Title: Keep working or not? Questions from a newbie Carla9112 lisalock

((hugs)) Michele

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 03:38PM chefmiche wrote: Thanks ladies, I looked into Texas High Risk Pool - but with my husb income I didn't think I qualified...:( I also asked my onc nurse yesterday about signing Accelerated Death benefit which for me is 1 x my annual salary (which isn't a whole lot, but would def help) but since it says I must die within 12 mo Dr won't sign that.  I wish!! I guess I will prob just pay the COBRA and have my husb get his own policy, maybe cheaper than it is for him to be on my Cobra. There are so many things to try to figure out, and without these boards, I wouldn't of known about half of them.  Thanks so much for all your comments!

Posts.Content: May 19, 2014 02:53PM chefmiche wrote: I get extreme bone pain after my Xgeva monthly injections, every bone on my body hurts for 3 days, 3 days after the injection, unless it is the Gemzar I am getting?? I wish I knew what was causing it and what stops it! Any idea?
Posts.Title: Xgeva for Bone Mets: Time on? Results? SEs? WanderingSpirit WanderingSpirit

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2012 06:53PM chefmiche wrote: I had the same decision to make, I was 36DD and surgeon advised to remove one breast and gave options for reconstruction but I was 36 yrs and thought, I never want to go through this cancer stuff again, so I asked if they could remove both.  She argued that there was no cancer in the right breast, but ultimately it was my decision and I opted for the DIEP reconstruction, which was a bonus, "tummy tuck", which I have loved.  Needless to say I now have cancer again anyway but I was quite happy with the reconstruction option.  I had chemo first, then bi-lateral masectomy, then radiation, then reconstruction.  So I was without breasts for a good 4 months, and I actually liked not having such huge boobs for those months, but being bald, no eyebrows, lashes, and no boobs all at the same time was a life changing experience for me.  I was single and working and had to come to the realization that I am not defined by my hair, or my boobs.  Cancer has really changed my priorities, as I am sure every person can say it changed them in many ways.  I chose to have B size reconstruction and was quite happy to be "normal" size and not have people look at my boobs instead of my eyes when talking to me. Good luck with whatever you decide, there are several options!

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2015 05:17PM chefmiche wrote: when I saw these stories it gave me hope! I mean the traditional methods, are not going to cure us... So why wouldn't I want to hear more like them that tried things that actually worked! Personally I don't feel comfortable continuing to go down the chemo path anymore it is just destroying my body w side effects. I applaud these brave women! Also look at chrisbeatcancer.com there is a lot of great info there also! A lot of negative responses here surprised me because I was so happy when I first saw topic and looked further after watching videos.... There is a place in US I would love to try that does a lot of the therapies Shannon did in Mexico. I just can't sit here waiting to die. I hope one day I am sharing my story not to make money or because I like the attention but because I beat an incurable disease and want to help others live too!! We will see where God leads us all.. Thank you for this topic!!!

Posts.Title: Sex and Cancer JeninMichigan Bestbird

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2012 12:01AM chefmiche wrote: I am glad to read this thread...thanks for all your honesty.  I have had this dx since Sept 2011 and in April was told the tumors are stable, there is no evidence of disease NED, I just got married in May to the most wonderful man in the world after waiting for him my whole life, my oncologist advised me to stop working prior to NED and after so now I am 41 yr old, newlywed and am sad all the time.  I keep thinking that any day I will find out the cancer is active again.  I can't seem to escape from it.  I don't want to feel this way because I feel that I have been given a second chance?  Maybe all the prayers have worked and it won't come back?  I should be ecstatic, hopeful.  I am to most people and do try to think positive but inside I worry all the time.  I hate it.  A rollercoaster is the best definition of how I feel...
Posts.Title: Stage IV Breast Cancer feels like . . . radiant Sanibelblueyezz

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2013 09:45AM chefmiche wrote: I have used caringbridge since 2007 when I was first diagnosed with BC (then stopped when I thought I was cured)  I picked it back up when dx with Mets in 2011 and I have always looked at posting there as a way to keep my loved ones informed without all the calls and emails but also in case anyone is reading may know of someone who is recently dx that may want to read about my experiences.  I always have hoped it might help someone.  Also since I have a horrible memory it was a way to journal things as they happened so I can refer back to it if I need to.  Also love to have all the guestbook posts to look through if I am having a down day.  I don't post there very often but have always gotten positive feedback from those reading it saying they are thankful to know what to pray for and to know how I am doing when they may be afraid to ask me....
Posts.Title: FB, caring bridge, others-need reviews Kellke Iwillwinthisbattle
